Utterance: Hi, it’s Ellie again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie. I’ve been okay, a bit overwhelmed with work stuff.
I see. What specifically has been overwhelming for you?
Well, I’m trying to juggle my singing gigs and my regular job, and it feels like there’s just not enough time in the day.
That sounds challenging. Have you been able to find any balance between the two?
Not really. I feel like I’m constantly rushing and not doing either one well.
It’s understandable to feel that way. Have you thought about any strategies to help manage your time better?
I’ve tried making schedules, but they never seem to stick. I get distracted easily.
What kinds of distractions do you find yourself facing?
Mostly social media and just... I don’t know, my mind wandering to other things.
That’s common. Have you tried setting specific time limits for those distractions?
I haven’t really. I guess I just let it happen.
It might help to set boundaries for yourself. For example, you could allocate certain times for social media and stick to those.
Yeah, I can see that. I just need to be more disciplined.
Discipline can be tough. What do you think is holding you back from being more disciplined?
I think it’s just my habit of procrastination. I tend to put things off until the last minute.
Procrastination can be a challenge. What do you usually do when you procrastinate?
I end up binge-watching shows or scrolling through my phone instead of focusing on what I need to do.
It sounds like a way to escape the pressure you’re feeling. How do you feel after you’ve spent time procrastinating?
Honestly? I feel guilty and stressed because I know I should be doing something else.
That’s a tough cycle to be in. Have you thought about trying to replace that procrastination with something more productive?
I guess I could try. Maybe I could set a timer for short bursts of work and then reward myself with a break.
That’s a great idea! It’s often easier to focus for shorter periods. How long do you think you could work before needing a break?
Maybe 25 minutes? That seems manageable.
That sounds perfect! You could use the Pomodoro technique. After 25 minutes, take a 5-minute break. How does that sound?
Yeah, I think I could do that. I’ll give it a shot.
Excellent! Let’s check in on that next session. How has your sleep been since we last talked?
It’s been a bit better, actually. My girlfriend has been helping me unwind at night.
That’s wonderful to hear! What does she do to help you unwind?
She usually suggests we watch something light or do a meditation together.
That sounds lovely. Have you found that meditation helps you relax?
Yes, I think it does. It’s nice to have that time together, too.
Connection can be very grounding. Have you considered incorporating meditation into your daily routine?
I’ve thought about it, but I haven’t committed to it yet.
It might be helpful to set a specific time for it, maybe even right before bed. Would you be open to trying that?
Yeah, I think I could try that. It might help me sleep better.
Great! Let’s aim for that. How about your feelings of self-criticism? Have you noticed any changes since our last conversation?
I’ve been trying to be more aware of it. It’s still there, but I catch myself more often.
That’s a positive step forward! What do you do when you catch yourself being self-critical?
I try to remind myself of the good things I’ve accomplished, like my singing.
That’s a wonderful strategy. Celebrating your achievements can help shift your focus. Can you think of one recent accomplishment you’re proud of?
I had a small gig last week, and I felt really good about my performance.
That’s fantastic! How did it feel to perform?
It felt amazing, like I was in my element. I love connecting with the audience.
That connection is so important. How can you create more opportunities for that?
I could look for more gigs or open mic nights. I’ve been hesitant, but I think I need to push myself.
It sounds like a great idea. What’s holding you back from pursuing more opportunities?
Fear of rejection, I guess. I worry that people won’t like my music.
That’s a common fear among artists. How do you usually cope with that fear?
I try to avoid thinking about it, but it’s always in the back of my mind.
It might be helpful to reframe that fear. Instead of focusing on rejection, what if you viewed it as a chance to grow and learn?
That’s a good perspective. I’ll try to think of it that way.
Great! Remember, every performance is an opportunity to improve. How about we set a goal for you to find one new gig before our next session?
I can do that! I’ll look into it.
Wonderful! I’m excited to hear about it. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
No, I think we covered a lot. Thank you!
You’re welcome! I look forward to hearing about your progress next time.
Bye, Ellie!
Goodbye!
